definitions: pull up or remove wild plants growing where they are not wanted
systematically remove unwanted or inferior items from a group
examples: She weeds her garden every Saturday morning
The children helped weed the vegetable patch yesterday
They need to weed out unqualified applicants quickly
The committee weeded through hundreds of proposals carefully

definitions: spend time during the period from Friday evening through Sunday
examples: They weekend at their cottage by the lake
We often weekend in the countryside during summer

definitions: express grief or sorrow by shedding tears from the eyes
slowly discharge liquid through small openings or pores
examples: She wept quietly during the memorial service
The child wept for hours after losing her toy
The wound continued to weep despite the bandage
Water weeps through the cracked basement wall constantly

definitions: find out how heavy something is using scales or similar equipment
carefully assess or consider the importance or value of something
have a particular weight when measured on a scale
examples: The nurse weighs each baby during monthly checkups
Please weigh these packages before shipping them today
She carefully weighed her options before deciding
The jury must weigh all the evidence presented
The suitcase weighs exactly twenty-three kilograms
This watermelon weighs more than fifteen pounds

definitions: make something heavier by adding extra weight or mass to it
assign different levels of importance or influence to various factors
examples: They weight the fishing nets to keep them underwater
The diver weighted his belt before descending
The survey weights responses based on demographic factors
Teachers weight final exams more heavily than quizzes

definitions: greet someone in a warm and friendly way upon their arrival
receive or accept something with pleasure or approval
examples: The host welcomed all the guests at the door
They welcomed us warmly into their beautiful home
The company welcomes feedback from all its customers
Most residents welcome the proposed park improvements

definitions: join pieces of metal together by heating edges until they fuse
bring people or things together into a strong unified whole
examples: The mechanic welded the broken exhaust pipe yesterday
She learned to weld steel plates in trade school
The crisis welded the community into a cohesive unit
Shared experiences welded them into lifelong friends

definitions: cover or saturate something with water or another liquid
accidentally discharge urine especially due to loss of bladder control
examples: The rain thoroughly wet the laundry hanging outside
She wet the sponge before cleaning the counter
The frightened puppy wet the carpet last night
Young children sometimes wet their beds while sleeping

definitions: hit something or someone hard with a sharp blow
murder someone especially as organized crime activity
examples: He whacked the ball over the fence yesterday
She whacked the piñata with all her strength
The mob boss ordered them to whack the informant
They planned to whack him after the trial

definitions: hunt and kill whales for their meat oil or other products
hit or strike something repeatedly with great force
examples: Ships would whale in Arctic waters for months
They whaled commercially until international bans began
The boxer whaled on his opponent mercilessly
The storm whaled against the coastal buildings

definitions: hit something with a loud sound or great impact
examples: The car whammed into the concrete barrier
He whammed his fist on the table angrily

definitions: move or transport something using wheels or a wheeled vehicle
turn around quickly in a circular movement especially to face another direction
examples: The nurse wheeled the patient to the operating room
They wheeled their bikes up the steep hill
The birds wheeled overhead in perfect formation
She wheeled around to face her accuser

definitions: get a brief smell or scent of something passing by
fail to hit something especially when swinging at a ball
examples: She whiffed the perfume as he walked past
I whiffed smoke coming from the kitchen
The batter whiffed on three straight pitches
He whiffed the golf ball completely

definitions: produce a long high-pitched sound expressing pain or distress
complain in an annoying persistent way about something
examples: The dog whined outside the door all night
The engine whined as it struggled uphill
Stop whining about having to do your homework
She constantly whines about her working conditions

definitions: strike a person or animal with a whip or similar implement
move very quickly or suddenly in a specified direction
beat cream eggs or similar ingredients until thick and foamy
examples: The jockey whipped his horse during the final stretch
Masters would cruelly whip enslaved people as punishment
The wind whipped through the narrow mountain pass
She whipped around the corner at high speed
Whip the cream until it forms stiff peaks
The chef whipped egg whites for the soufflé

definitions: move or cause to move rapidly around and around
move or happen so quickly as to create confusion or excitement
examples: The dancers whirled across the ballroom floor gracefully
She whirled the baton during the parade performance
Events whirled past in a confusing blur
My thoughts whirled as I tried to understand

definitions: speak very softly using breath without vocal cords
spread information or rumors privately and quietly among people
examples: She whispered the secret in his ear carefully
The students whispered during the exam
People whispered about the scandal for weeks
Rumors whispered through the small town quickly

definitions: produce a clear high sound by forcing breath through pursed lips
summon signal or express something by making a whistling sound
examples: He whistled a cheerful tune while working
The kettle whistled loudly on the stove
The referee whistled to stop the play
She whistled for her dog to come inside

definitions: make something white or whiter through bleaching or similar process
apply white coloring or covering to a surface
examples: The sun whited the old wooden fence naturally
Years of washing whited the colored fabric
They whited out the mistake with correction fluid
Snow whited the entire landscape overnight

definitions: paint a wall or building with whitewash liquid
deliberately conceal or gloss over wrongdoing scandals or unpleasant facts
examples: They whitewashed the old barn last summer
Workers whitewashed the fence around the property
The report whitewashed the company's environmental violations
Officials tried to whitewash the corruption scandal

definitions: carve wood into a shape by repeatedly cutting small pieces
gradually reduce the size or amount of something through repeated small reductions
examples: Grandfather whittled wooden toys for the children
He whittled a walking stick from an oak branch
They whittled down the list to three candidates
Rising costs whittled away their savings significantly

definitions: move very quickly through the air with a buzzing sound
urinate in informal or slang usage
examples: Cars whizzed past on the busy highway
The bullet whizzed by his ear dangerously
He needed to whiz before the long journey
The child asked to whiz during the movie

definitions: sell goods in large quantities to retailers rather than consumers
examples: They wholesale clothing to department stores nationwide
The company wholesales electronic components to manufacturers

definitions: give a loud cry of excitement enthusiasm or joy
examples: The crowd whooped when their team scored
Children whooped with delight at the surprise party

definitions: work as a prostitute engaging in sexual activity for payment
debase oneself or one's talents for money or unworthy purposes
examples: She was forced to whore to support her addiction
Women who whored faced arrest and imprisonment
He whored his artistic talent for commercial success
The politician whored himself to corporate interests

definitions: make something broader or more extensive in width or scope
become broader or more extensive in width or scope
examples: They plan to widen the highway next year
The scandal widened the rift between them significantly
Her eyes widened in surprise at the news
The gap between rich and poor continues to widen

definitions: cause someone to become a widow by the death of their spouse
examples: The war widowed thousands of young women
She was widowed at the age of thirty-five

definitions: hold and use a weapon or tool effectively and purposefully
have and use power influence or authority in a situation
examples: The knight wielded his sword with great skill
She wielded the hammer to drive in nails
The president wields enormous power over foreign policy
He wielded his influence to change the decision

definitions: move with short quick movements from side to side or up and down
examples: The puppy wiggled its tail excitedly
She wiggled her toes in the warm sand

definitions: make something happen by mental determination or desire
leave property to someone in a legal will after death
examples: She willed herself to stay awake during class
He willed the pain to go away
She willed her estate to her favorite charity
He willed the house to his eldest daughter

definitions: become limp and drooping as a plant from heat or lack of water
lose energy strength or vigor often from heat or exhaustion
examples: The flowers wilted in the afternoon sun
Lettuce wilts quickly without proper refrigeration
The runners wilted in the extreme heat
Her enthusiasm wilted after repeated rejections

definitions: be successful or victorious in a contest or competition
acquire or secure something as a result of effort or competition
examples: Our team won the championship game last night
She won first place in the science fair
He won her heart with his kindness
They won approval for their innovative proposal

definitions: lift or pull something using a winch mechanical device
examples: They winched the boat onto the trailer
Workers winched heavy equipment to the roof

definitions: wrap something around itself or another object in coils or spirals
follow a twisting or spiral course through an area
examples: She wound the yarn into a neat ball
He wound the clock every Sunday morning
The river winds through the valley peacefully
The path wound up the steep mountainside

definitions: entertain someone by providing them with wine
drink wine especially in a social setting
examples: They wined and dined their important clients
The host wined his guests generously
We wined at the vineyard all afternoon
They often wine together after work

definitions: fly or travel quickly through the air
do something without preparation relying on improvisation
examples: Birds winged south for the winter migration
The plane winged its way across the ocean
She had to wing her presentation without notes
The actor winged it when he forgot his lines

definitions: close and open one eye quickly as a signal or greeting
shine or flash intermittently like a blinking light
examples: She winked at him across the crowded room
He winked to show he was joking
Stars winked in the clear night sky
The lighthouse winked through the fog

definitions: spend the winter season in a particular place or way
examples: Many birds winter in warmer southern regions
They winter in Florida every year

definitions: clean or dry something by rubbing with a cloth or hand
remove or eliminate something completely from existence or memory
examples: She wiped the table with a damp cloth
He wiped his tears with a handkerchief
The virus wiped out entire villages
One mistake could wipe out their savings

definitions: install electrical wires or connections in a building or device
send a message by telegraph or cable communication
transfer money electronically through a bank or service
examples: They wired the new house last week
The electrician wired the alarm system properly
Reporters wired stories from the battlefield
She wired the news to headquarters immediately
Please wire the payment to this account today
They wired money to their son overseas

definitions: secretly listen to or record telephone or electronic communications
examples: Federal agents wiretapped the suspect's phone calls
They illegally wiretapped private conversations for months

definitions: feel or express a strong desire for something to happen
express a hope or desire for someone's wellbeing or success
examples: She wished she could travel the world
I wish this rain would stop soon
We wish you a happy birthday today
They wished him luck on his journey

definitions: remove or take away something from a particular place or position
remove oneself from participation in an activity or commitment
examples: She withdrew money from her savings account
The nurse withdrew blood for testing
The company withdrew from the European market
He withdrew his candidacy before the election

definitions: become dry and shriveled especially of plants losing moisture
cause to decline or be destroyed especially through harsh criticism
examples: The plants withered during the summer drought
Leaves wither and fall in autumn
Her confidence withered under constant criticism
His withering remarks destroyed their enthusiasm

definitions: refuse to give or grant something that is due or desired
examples: The company withheld payment until work was completed
She withheld information from the investigators

definitions: remain undamaged or unaffected by something harmful or powerful
examples: The building withstood the earthquake remarkably well
She withstood intense pressure to change her position

definitions: move unsteadily from side to side with an uneven rocking motion
examples: The table wobbles because one leg is shorter
She wobbled on her high heels

definitions: eat food quickly and greedily in large amounts
examples: He wolfed down his dinner in five minutes
The hungry children wolfed their sandwiches eagerly

definitions: desire to know something or feel curious about something
feel admiration and amazement at something remarkable or unfamiliar
examples: I wonder what happened to our old neighbors
She wondered if he would ever call
Tourists wonder at the ancient pyramids
Children wonder at the magic show

definitions: try to gain the love of someone especially with a view to marriage
seek the favor support or custom of someone through persuasion
examples: He wooed her with flowers and poetry
The prince wooed the princess for months
Politicians woo voters with campaign promises
Companies woo customers with special offers
